loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina T. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years-old and married with five adult children. Avelina owns and operates a service-based business providing manicures and pedicures to local community members. Avelina has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Avelina joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avelina is requesting a first loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide the service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel D. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years-old and married with two school-aged children. Maricel owns and operates a specialized retail store which sells ready to wear products like jeans, shirts, and more in the local community. Maricel is just starting this business.

In 2009, Maricel joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel is requesting a first loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products.

loans.name: Fhe

texts.en:
Fhe M. S., 33, was born on June 4, 1976 and is a native of Leyte, a province South of Manila. She is married to Isagani R. S. and together they have two children. Their eldest is now in elementary school, while the youngest is still too young to study. They currently live at Silang Cavite, which is a two hour drive from Manila. Their main source of income is selling livestock feed and gas for cooking.

Fhe has been a member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now and has received a loan from CCT five times already. She is a regular partner who always pays her dues on time. Aside from the loans she received, CCT also offers bible studies in weekly fellowships so that they can learn and live the teachings of God written in His Word. Now she is more open and curious about studying the bible than ever before. Their fellowship group meets every Thursday at 10-11:30 am.

She is currently applying for a loan worth PHP 15,000 for the expansion of her business. She believes that with this amount, she can buy additional stocks for her poultry feed and gas reserves for her regular clients, enabling her to increase her profits and a chance for a better living.

loans.use: To buy assorted feeds and gas.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en: Presentacion V. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 50 years old, is married, and has nine school-aged children. Presentacion owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Presentacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Mr. Sun V., 20, is a single man and resides in Phnom Penh city. Presently, he works as internal staff in the marketing department for a private school and earns a salary of $150 each month. Sun V. dreams of having a new enterprise but he does not have the capital to start it. Recently, he borrowed a loan of from Kiva through HKL to be used to operate a phone sale business.

loans.use: To operate a phone sale business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene V., 40, is a vegetable, meat, and fish vendor. She was born in Camarines Sur, Bicol, a province down south of Luzon. Today, she lives with her husband and family in Pasay, Metro Manila. Blessed with five children, she and her husband Rolando are teaming up to expand their business for their family. Arlene has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her loans was because she used almost all of the money she borrowed to buy assorted vegetables for her business.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 48,000 loan. This amount will be used to expand her business with additional assorted vegetables, meat, and fish.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that when the time comes, they can have the resources to buy a lot or a market space where they can put up their own vegetable/meat store.  

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional assorted vegetables, meat and fish.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en: Rosario S. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old, is widowed, and has seven adult children. Rosario owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling eggs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou G. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 26 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Marilou owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling coconuts in the local community. At the same time she is engaged in making and selling charcoal from coconut shells. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita, 55, and her husband Domingo are busy with their lives and for good reason, they have three businesses:  a sidecar service, a vegetable stand, and bed space for rent. They are blessed with two children, one who is now working and the other one who passed away.

Rosita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times from CCT’s Cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her loans was because she used almost all of the money she borrowed to improve her business. 

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 19,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used  to buy an additional pedi-cab for their transportation service and to increase vegetable stocks for more profits. 

She dreams that all her businesses will continue to grow so that they can have more savings and see more opportunities to start new businesses in the future.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy an additional pedi-cab for their transportation service and added vegetable stocks for more profits.

loans.name: Hen

texts.en: Hen R. is a young married man, who lives in the rural area outside of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He is 22 and is married to Senghoeun who is 23 and works sewing clothes in the garment factory. The couple currently has two small kids who are still not enrolled in school. Hen R. has been earning a living by supplying a taxi service, and he makes $3 of income per day to manage his family’s daily living. Hen R. currently resides in a very old house that is frequently broken down and affects his and his family's living situation. Thus, Hen R. is looking for a loan to decorate/repair his old house.

loans.use: To decorate/repair his old house.

loans.name: Arline

texts.en:
Arline R. G., 31, was born on December 6, 1977. She is married to Victor G. and they are blessed with one child who is in elementary school. She and her family live in Silang, Cavite, a province just South of Manila.

Arline has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for three years. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow twelve times from CCT’s Cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her loans was because she used almost all of the money she borrowed to buy and sell assorted feeds to her increasing consumer base.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 26,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used to buy additional stocks of rice, different beverages and assorted canned goods for her variety store.

She prays that her business will continue to grow so that one day it will become a mini-grocery. She hopes that some day they will have enough money to send their child to college and that they will have a chance to travel around the world.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of rice, different beverages, and assorted canned goods for her variety store.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is 27 years of age. She rents a one-roomed house where she stays with her family of five people. They have three meals a day and her greatest expense in a month is paying tuition for her children.

Jamila sells used clothes and she works six days a week, serving about six customers a day. She also has a side business of sewing which adds to her income

Jamila has been with MCDT for three years now and she has so far received six loans. She will use this loan to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Moises

texts.en:
Moises M. is from the village of Pines. He is 61 years old, is married, and has one infant child.

Moises owns and operates a photo-lamination business, providing photo-lamination services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Moises joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. 

Moises is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be his first from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 36 years of age. She lives in her own two-room house where she currently lives with six people. She has three meals a day. Her three greatest expenses in a month are paying electricity bills.

Regina has a retail shop and she works seven days a week. She serves about thirty customers a day. She has done this for business for fifteen years now. She also runs a pay phone that brings in some side income for her family. Her main challenge is that there are many retail shops that sell the same products as she does.

She has been with MCDT for 5 years now and so far she has taken 12 loans. She has worked with her group for five years now. She will use this loan to pay tuition for her children and also to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her retail shop

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling bananas in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Aida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen sells Nigerian cooked foods to make a living in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is 49 years old and is married with 7 children. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. She is a LAPO client. The Lift above poverty organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is a hardworking woman. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda, 27, is a young mother who balances her schedule between her three grade school children and her sideline businesses of direct selling cosmetics, assorted biscuits, and frozen meat foods. Married to Michael F. who is a security guard, she makes it a point to help her husband with their daily expenses by contributing what she earns. 

Esmeralda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than six years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow fifteen times from CCT’s Cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her loans was because she used almost all of the money borrowed as added capital for her business.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used to expand her business by buying additional cosmetics for her increasing number of clients.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can help with the family’s daily expenses and be able to let their children all finish their studies someday. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microminance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional cosmetics.

loans.name: Erlinda

Erlinda owns and operates a business planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 14th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Okiemure

texts.en: Okiemure is a fashion designer and she designs lovely Nigerian designs for her customers. She also sells sarongs at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her immediate family members. She is married with 6 children and she is 39 years old. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 35 years old, and she is married with 5 children. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. During the holidays, her children assist with sales. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells sarongs and lace in the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more sarongs and lace to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and lace to sell

loans.name: Vaniza

texts.en:
Vaniza S. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 22 years old. Vaniza is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Vaniza owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling coated and salted peanuts in the local community. Vaniza has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vaniza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vaniza is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Vaniza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

To make a living, Ramil owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. In 2009, Ramil joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramil is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ramil from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma M. is from the village of Sta. Rosa, Gamu,Isabela. She is 56 years old. Gemma is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Gemma is married and has adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables and street foods in the local community. With her vending business, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells jewelry and bags in the market to make a living. She lives in Warri Delta State; She is a focused, hard worker. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 42 years old and married with 5 children. Her eldest child is 28 years old. She is requesting for a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more jewelry and bags to sell. She is a LAPO client. The Lift above poverty organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry and bags to sell

loans.name: Ana Margie

texts.en:
Ana Margie D. is 29 years old and is from the village of Talinga. She is married to Alfredo and their marriage is blessed with three kids. Her husband (shown in the photo) is a baker and currently operates a small bakery in their house which specializes in the production of hardened bread, popularly known in their locality as "binangkal".

Ana Margie helps her husband in managing their business. She is responsible for the repacking procedures and for some marketing aspects.

Ana Margie has a good credit record and is currently utilizing her second loan from the Cooperative. She started her Cooperative affiliation last year and she manifests a good repayment status.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her miniature bakery

location.town: Talinga, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
A business-minded woman, Imelda Camaraeg is 30 years old and the mother of two (2) daughters and two (2) sons. She is married to Joserizal M., who is 33 years old, but her husband is living with another woman. Therefore, Imelda is now the head of the family and the provider for her four (4) children. She lives in Antipolo, in the province of Rizal, Philippines.

With her faith to get out of poverty, Imelda decided in 2008 to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, for the chance to have start-up capital for generating income. During her 1st, 2nd, and 3rd loans with ASHI, she carefully invested in the buying and selling of Avon products. The profit is what she uses for daily expenses and to meet the educational needs of her children. Now for her 4th loan, she proposes to borrow Php 20,000.00 pesos for a broader business. Specifically, the amount will be use to purchase body lotion, lipstick, pressed powder, cologne, bras, underwear for all ages, etc. Imelda is very determined and disciplined to use the money which was lent to her in her previous loans from ASHI.

She still dreams of the best for her family, especially to provide the best education for her children and have a happy family. During almost two (2) years in ASHI, Lolita has shown herself to be hard-working and strong-minded for making her dreams come true. She hopes that her business will expand so here children will have savings for future use. She is grateful to ASHI for supporting people like her who wants to grow their standard of living. She is also happy seeing that the loans from ASHI changes their lives and accommodate their financial means needed to support her families. She wishes ASHI and all lenders all the best and hopes they will keep on supporting her family and other families who are in need.

loans.use: To buy body lotion, lipstick, pressed powder, cologne, bras, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza A. is a 39-year-old and a member of ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.) in the western part of the province, Antipolo, Rizal where many marketplaces are located. Analiza sells frozen food products to support the needs of her four children. She is married to Pedro A., 40 years old, a tricycle (three-wheeled public transport vehicle) driver and a supportive husband.

In 2008, Analiza joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines, to continue pursuing her family dreams. She utilized her previous loans from ASHI wisely for her business and she manages it well and brings in good proceeds. Analiza wants to continue her frozen foods business and make more savings from it.

She has applied for her 4th loan amounting to Php 15,000 to pay for a variety of frozen food products like hotdogs, cheese dogs, 'tapa', 'longganisa', 'tocino', 'embutido', patties, etc. She wants to build a stall in the market to accommodate the needs of her customers and to give her family a good income.

She will try her best to manage this business to assist her children's education. She is grateful for the trust of the lenders, who are making this loan possible. She hopes that her membership in ASHI will help her achieve her greatest dreams in life. She would love to have an expanded business and her own house to live in.

loans.use: pay for a variety of frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
A used clothing dealer locally known as “okay-okay” and a "sari-sari" (variety) store operator is our featured entrepreneur of this story. She is Mrs. Rebecca T., 40 years of age, married and a resident of P1 San Apolinario, Tangub City. She is married to Rene T., who drives their motor cab for hire. Unfortunately, the couple are still not blessed with any children.

They started this "okay-okay" and sari-sari store business a year ago, and at this time they are earning an average net income of not less than 10,000 PHP. Her husband is also earning an average net income of 9,700 PHP a month from service as a motorcab driver. Rebecca joined PAGLAUM MPC just this year because she is very much interested in our products and services as we are one of the outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao, awarded Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

With her good credit record based on her 1st loan history, she is given the privilege of accessing the amount of 50,000 PHP to add to her capital for her existing "okay-okay'" business. Their future plan in life is to have an additional outlet or display stand for their "okay-okay" business. The future income from this loan is for basic needs and savings for their family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her "okay-okay" business

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is forty-eight years old. She is divorced and has given birth to five children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community in the central region of Ghana.

Grace is a petty trader. She trades in second-hand clothes. She hawks (walks around to sell) and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for four years and desires to give her business a face-lift. Grace therefore wants the loan to procure bales of textile goods.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes by the bale

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn T. is from the village of Map-an. She is 37 years old. Merlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns & operates a banana buying & selling business out of a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling bananas in the local community. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for this activity.

In 2009, Merlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Merlyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia C. is from the village of San Andres. She is 61 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children.

Amalia owns and operates a clothing business, providing general clothing services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Amalia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.

Amalia is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 33 years old, married, and has 4 children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Fatima, like many other women in the community, works to support her husband to provide for the family. For the past 10 years, she has been working as a food vendor, preparing and selling yam and rice with stew, and hawking to sell in the mornings. To prepare her dishes, Fatima buys bags of rice from nearby communities. Currently, she needs a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase of bags of rice

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is 49 years old and married with 4 children. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina F., 41 years old, comes from Antipolo, province of Rizal, which is currently a fast-growing area in terms of business activity. Carolina is married to Eduardo, 34, who works as a tricycle driver.  She has 5 children, between the ages of 4 and 12, all of whom are still dependent on her.
Carolina husband's income is insufficient to provide for the needs of their family; therefore, in 2003, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She was given hope and access to capital, so she started her frozen foods business. The business has been going smoothly and ensures good income for the family. Carolina would like to continue the business and invest more in it.

Currently, Carolina is on her 6th loan, borrowing PHP 30,000 as additional capital to purchase stock and more supplies for her Frozen Foods Business. Stock includes tocino, embutido, hotdogs, longganisa, ham, meat loaf, tapa, and other supplies. Carolina has disciplined herself to use all of the borrowed capital from ASHI-KIVA for her business, to gain more profit and to use that profit to cover the daily expenses.

During the past 6 years that she has been a member of ASHI, Carolina has been able to make it possible to send her children to school, so that they can obtain a degree in the future and be able to provide for their families. Carolina is very thankful to ASHI for the kind hearted support of her dreams and hopes to be able to eventually afford to build or purchase a house for her family.

loans.use: Purchase of embutido, longganisa, ham, and other frozen food products for sale

loans.name: Kwadwo

texts.en: Kwadwo is 51 years old, married, and has three children, all still in school.  He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a coastal community in the central region of Ghana, which is a popular tourist destination. Kwadwo earns income running a drug store by the roadside in his community. Kwadwo has been in this business for over 11 years now and currently needs a loan to buy drugs in bulk to increase the stock in his store.

loans.use: Purchase of drugs for sale

loans.name: Endurance

texts.en: Endurance is 36 years old, and she is married with children. She is a hardworking woman. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells groceries and loaves of bread to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting for the loan amount to purchase more groceries and loaves of bread to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and loaves of bread to sell

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: Francisca is 32 years old, married, and has four children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. Francisca earns income trading foodstuffs, such as plantain and potatoes. She buys her goods from nearby towns and sells to food vendors in her community. Francisca has been in this business for six years now and currently neds a loan to procure foodstuffs in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta is 30 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. Benedicta earns income trading in foodstuffs such as plantain and potatoes. She also sells kenkey and oranges by the road side. Benedicta buys her goods from nearby towns and sells to food vendors in her community. Benedicta has been in this business for ten years and currently needs a loan to procure additional products in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: A. Hasan was born in 1983. He is single and lives in the Fuzuli region. Hasan earns income operating his own auto repair business, which he started 3 years ago. Now, he needs a loan of AZN 2,000 to buy spare auto parts to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase of spare auto parts

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet sells local gin in the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. Local gin is also known as Ogogoro in Nigeria. The demands for her local gin are high, and she hopes to meet the demands of her numerous customers. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is married with 12 children. She is 48 years old. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more local gin to sell. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame is 28 years old, married, and has three children who are all still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. Maame earns income selling potatoes, kenkey, and other foodstuffs. She buys her goods from nearby towns and sells them to food vendors in her community and by the roadside. Maame has been in this business for 8 years and currently needs a loan to procure additional foodstuffs in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christina is 27 years old, divorced, and has a child who is still in school. She lives with her son in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Christina works as a seamstress, designing and sewing dresses for sale. She works in a shop in her community, located by the roadside. Christina has been operating her business for almost a year now, and currently needs a loan to improve it.  She plans to use the loan to buy fabrics and other accessories in bulk to achieve this dream.

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics for a sewing business

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is married with 3 children, and she is 36 years old. Her husband is a police officer. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells foodstuffs like garri (a local specialty) at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 52 years old, married, and has eight children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Mary works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She is a food vendor, preparing and selling kenkey with fried fish. Mary buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities and sells her prepared dish by the roadside. She has been in this business for over twenty years now, and currently needs a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase of bags of maize

loans.name: Pyotr

texts.en:
Pyotr is married and lives in Zaporozhye, where he operates his own vending store, selling groceries and household chemicals. He has been in this business for 10 years now and, because of his determination and customer-friendly attitude, his venture has been very successful. Currently, he has 50,000 Grivnyas in inventory and his profit amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Pyotr currently needs a loan of 10,900 Grivnyas to increase his turnover capital. He believes that this loan will help him re-supply his inventory and encourage more customers to come and shop in his store. Increased sales, in turn, will generate the necessary funds to sustain the business as well as help him meet his family’s needs.

loans.use: Increase in working capital

loans.name: Erika

texts.en:
Erika is single. She runs a small enterprise selling women’s outer wear in the market called “Image” in her home town of Beregovo. Erika owns a nice, spacious vending kiosk where she offers a wide assortment of merchandise at reasonable prices. She is a young and promising entrepreneur with only a year and a half of market business experience. Presently, Erika already has 60,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory. Her net profit amounts to 5,500 Grivnyas a month.  
 
Erika is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional inventory for further retail sale in her kiosk. She says this type of merchandise is always in demand among her customers. Erika wants to continue expanding her venture and reach a stable standing in the competitive market.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Joke

texts.en: Joke sells pastries like chin-chin. Chin-chin is made from flour and sugar. She is 46 years old and she is married with 2 children. She is a friendly woman. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more bags of flour to fry more chin-chin to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of flour to fry more chin-chin to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is twenty two years old. She is single and has no children. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to be able to provide for herself. She trades in pastries. She prepares and supplies pastries to other retailers in her community. Josephine also sells some of her pastries by the road side. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour

loans.name: Rosemond

texts.en:
Rosemond is a forty-two year old married mother of three children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. 

Rosemond works hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She hawks to sell. Rosemond buys bags of rice from nearby towns. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is a 44 year old woman. She is married with eight children who are currently in school. She lives at Offinsu in the Ashanti region of Ghana. 

She is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew. Her food is moderately priced and very tasty, so for that reason lots of people buy from her stand. She says demand for her food is on the high side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for eight years now and her proceeds are used to take care of the children's school bills. 

She wants to use the loan to buy meat and rice to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her husband and to provide for her family.  She dreams of being able to provide her children with a better education to give them brighter future.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 55 years old, married and the father of four children. He lives in a small community which is a suburb of Offinsu in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Currently all of his children are in school. 

He runs a chemical store and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, malaria drugs, etc. in his neighborhood.  Many local people patronize his drugs as first aid and for cures when they are sick. He has been in business for five years now. He is among the few people who run a licensed chemical shop in the community. His chemical shop is registered to operate by the Ghana pharmaceutical council. 

He wants to use the loan to buy an increased supplies of drugs to include others that are frequently requested by his customers. He hopes to make a good income to take care of his family. This would enable him save more money to support his children in school.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs.

loans.name: Eloho

texts.en: Eloho sells baby things like bottles, clothes, cream and toys. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her stall. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is 43 years old and she is married with 6 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more baby things to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things to sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is married with 7 children and she is 54 years old. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells used clothes in the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. The demands for her used clothes are high by those in her community that cannot afford new clothes. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more  used clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
Gulbahor K. lives in Djabbar Rasulov, Tajikistan. Her husband works far away from home. They have one child of school age. Since he is in school, she has to spend money on his education and her husband doesn’t earn enough money to cover the schooling. She is responsible for caring for two cows. Gulbahor wants to borrow 5,000 TJS to buy more calves. She hopes in that way to earn more money and to be able to cover all the expenses of her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Ergashboy

texts.en:
Y. Ergashboy is 43 years old. He is married with two adorable children. Ergashboy has always opted to make his life on his land, work hard, and grow with it. That is how he decided to raise cattle and dedicate himself to agriculture. Ergashboy has been doing this kind of work for a very long time for he comes from a family with an entirely agricultural background. Today he wishes to increase the number of his animals and for this reason, he would like to buy cattle with the hope of increasing his income and the well-being of his home with the innumerable benefits that these special animals provide him. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 5,000 Somoni. Extend your solidarity to Ergashboy so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is married with 5 children and she is 44 years old. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells gently used clothes in the market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. The demands for her fairly used clothes are high by those in her community that cannot afford new clothes. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more nice used clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gently used clothes to sell

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
A. Rustam is 48 years old. He is married with nine children. For more than 10 years, Rustam has been running a joiner’s shop, manufacturing wooden doors and window frames. His elder son (pictured) is also involved in this business. The current business is quite profitable and generates a stable income, allowing Rustam to support his family and improve their living conditions. Rustam is respected as a good master in his neighborhood. Now he needs to purchase input materials for his manufacturing shop. For this purpose, he requests 6,000 Somoni. Rustam promises to repay his loan on time and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To purchase input materials for his manufacturing needs.

loans.name: Sharofiddin

texts.en:
B. Sharofiddin is 33 years old. He is married and has four children. Sharofiddin has a middle special education. His specialization is engineering. But he went into agrobusiness because the salary for engineers was small. And with a small salary, he has to feed his family and pay for his children’s education. Sharofiddin works hard to cultivate his products and raise cattle. He works from early morning until late at night hoping to have a rich harvest. He gets assistance by his brother with whom he was pictured. Sharofiddin sells his products at the market where they are always in high demand due to their good quality. His work fills him with great optimism and allows him to help his beloved children. His goal is to improve the quality of his agricultural products even more and expand his cattle breeding business. Today Sharofiddin is requesting a loan of $2000 USD to buy greater quantities of seeds, fertilizer and small cattle. Let's help Sharofiddin as he works hard to improve the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer and cattle

loans.name: Bayram

texts.en: Bayram is married and has three children. He was born in 1962. M.'s family lives in Baku city. His runs an auto repair business. Bayram has been in this business for five years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy the necessary things to improve his business

loans.name: Hikmatullo

texts.en:
D. Hikmatullo lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan where he was born in 1958. With God's help, he has become an excellent supplier of vegetables for his community. He is responsible for seven people (his wife and six children) and earns his family's living with his farming. Hikmatullo knows all the ins and outs of this business. He has 13 years of experience. His greatest triumph is his production of vegetables in the off-season. However, in order to accomplish this, he needs to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of $3,000 USD to be able to supply enough vegetables to meet the demand. This will allow him to better provide for his family. Let's help Hikmatullo as he works hard to improve the quality of life for his family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo sells sarongs and clothes to make a living. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She is married with 2 children and she is 33 years old. She is hardworking woman. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
D. Ilhomjon is 28 years old. He is married with two children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuff like cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, and tea in his grocery store which he built five years ago. Today Ilhomjon is requesting a loan of 4500 Somoni. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children will progress by means of their studies, for which Ilhomjon is working hard. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of the foodstuffs for a small grocery store.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is a hair stylist and she also sells hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. She makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. Her customers are usually friends, neighbors and residents. Helen is married with a child and she is 32 years old. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Kitagwenda Rwenzori Sacco Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Vincent M. is the leader of his group in Ibanda. He is 30 years old and married with three children aged 6, 3 and 1. Vincent has had a retail shop in Kitagwenda trading centre for 11 years and he is grateful for his loans because they have helped him increase the stock in his shop as well as to pay fees for his children.  He hopes to educate his children to the highest level of education. This is Vincent’s first loan with the group and he hopes to buy more sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, and other items all in bulk so that he might be able to make more profit to pay for his children’s education.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil and other items for a general store.

loans.name: Khursand

texts.en:
N. Khursand is 63 years old. She is married with six children. Khursand sells fabric from which the national dress is made. She has been in this business almost for 20 years.

Khursand has very good taste and she is ready to advise her clients which textile to choose for this or that occasion. Moreover, Khursand’s prices for fabrics are attractive for various levels of the population as she has a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet. She has two trading places in different markets.

All this allows her to keep her clientele and to make a good income. Now Khursand needs 7000 Somoni for purchasing new fabric in order to increase the range of goods that she sells. Khursand promises to repay the loan without any violation and expresses her gratitude to everyone that supports her.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the new fabrics in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Kamoliddin

texts.en:
Kamoliddin is married with two children. His family lives in Tursunzade, Tajikistan. Kamoliddin has a grocery sales business. His business boasts fresh groceries, reasonable prices, flexible and quality client service, and uniqueness and variety of merchandise. Kamoliddin works hard to develop his business and make his business profitable. He is requesting a loan of $2000 USD to reconstruct and modernize his vending pavilion, increase turnover capital and purchase an assortment of goods for retail sale. Kamoliddin has personal goals too. He is planning to use the generated profits to buy a new vehicle and remodel his private house. Kamoliddin is a conscientious and focused manager of his resources and always plans his time and finances. In all his business dealings, he is guided by a sense of trust and goodwill towards others. We believe these qualities will help him repay his loan without any delinquencies.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for increasing the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Ravza

texts.en:
Ravza P. is 55 years old. She is married with two children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has two cows and two calves. Now Ravza wants to expand her business, and as her children are grown up she thinks that she will be able to look after more cattle with their help. So she is asking for $1200 USD in order to purchase cattle. Ravza expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. loans.use: To purchase small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Anthonia

texts.en: Anthonia sells kerosene at the front of her house in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to be a major kerosene distributor in the future. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 11 years old. She is 35 years old. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 22 years old and sells snacks such as mandazis and samosas to neighbors and passerbys. She hopes to use the loan in order to increase her stock and buy flour and oil at wholesale prices, so she can make a profit. She has been in the business for 5 years. She is married and her husband is unemployed. They have three children who are 6, 8 and 9 years old. The oldest child is adopted.

She hopes to improve her business to educate her children and pay rent. She also hopes to someday become a supplier of her products to retail outlets. She describes herself as industrious and honest.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married with 2 children and she is 31 years old. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is hardworking. She sells sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina sells medicine to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a maternity home in the future. She is a LAPO client. She is 38 years old and married and she has four children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She has been in this business for a long time.

She is requesting for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders

The Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and throughtout Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Mpasha Bamwe Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Rose A., 32, is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is a determined and very hard working lady with a retail shop business that she has owned for 2 years. Before this shop business, Rose was a housewife involved in farming, until the proceeds helped her open up her retail shop.

She has been able to repay her loan with ease and she is now seeking another. She says that her good customer care and general organization have helped her succeed in business and she is now be able to make 200,000UGX as profits per month. She hopes to expand her shop further. Rose is married with 4 children aged 1-13 years, and 3 of them are in school. She also cares for 1 dependant. She has a dream of seeing all her children attend school and have the best education for self-reliance. She needs a loan to be able to restock her shop with more goods like bean seeds, maize flour, baking flour, sugar, cooking oil, bread and so on to avoid running out of stock.

loans.use: To restock her shop with more goods.

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en:
Bolaji is 42 years old and married. She has three children, the eldest of whom is 15 years old. Her husband sells spare parts for motors to support their family. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client.

Bolaji sells groceries at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a 33 year old married lady with three children, who are all in school. She has a second hand clothing business. She has been in business for 2 years. Since being a member of the Faulu, Esther has been able to plan ahead.

Esther has requested a loan to add more stock, such as socks, caps, sweaters, and jumpers. She hopes to have a well-established business in the future and to have a stable family life. Esther describes herself as a determined and focused lady.

loans.use: To add stock such as socks, caps, sweaters, and jumpers.

loans.name: Serifat

texts.en:
Serifat is 33 years old. She is married and has two children, the eldest of whom is just 3 years old. Her husband is a contractor and he helps to support their family. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client.

Serifat sells groceries and medicine at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and medicine to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and medicine to sell

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
Iyabo is 36 years old. She is married and has two children, the eldest of whom is 10 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband is an engineer and he helps to support their family. She is a LAPO client.

Iyabo sells medicine at retail prices. Her customers are mostly residents and friends. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 37 years old and married. She has five children, the eldest of whom is 16 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband has a poultry farm that helps to support their family. She is a LAPO client.

Mary sells electronics at retail prices. Her customers are mostly residents and friends. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dasola

texts.en:
Dasola is 52 years old. She is married and has two children, the eldest of whom is 29 years old. Her husband is a civil servant who helps to support their family. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client.

Dasola sells groceries and rents video disks (VCDs) at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Kazo Women In Development Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Justine N. is 33 years old and married with 3 children in primary school, and has had a retail shop business in Kazo town for 5 years. Justine is able to make 30,000UGX in profits per week and these help her with her children’s school fees and general upkeep. She attributes her success to the good customer care and the help of loans that enable her to stock the necessary goods. Her goal is to ensure that she expands her business, and her family stays healthy. Justine needs a loan to help inject more money into her business hence more profits. She is such a determined and hard working lady.

loans.use: To buy more goods to expand her retail shop.

loans.name: Waukae Group

texts.en:
Mwashambani G., age 42, is married and has three children, ages 8, 9, and 29 years old.  She has a café where she sells local foods, such as tea, mandazi (a donut-like pastry), chapati (a flat bread, like tortillas), chips, wali (rice) and ugali (a hot, sticky dough made from maize flour). She earns a monthly profit of around $210.

This will be Mwashambani’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes to obtain a loan to expand her business.
	
Mwashambani will share this loan with her loan group, Waukae, which has 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable when repaying the loan. In the photo, Mwashambani is in the back row wearing a blue dress.

loans.use: To make traditional foods for a small cafe

loans.name: Akatongore Sacco Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Prossy A. is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 31 years old and married with 3 children, who are all in primary and secondary schools. She also takes care of 1 dependant. Prossy has a hotel and retail shop business in Akatongore Migina, both businesses that she has owned for 8 years. She is able to make 100,000UGX as profit per week and this is mostly attributed to the good customer care and the help of loans. Prossy has a dream of getting a good house and big land for her family, as well as educating her children. She needs a loan to help add more stock and value to her business for growth and development. Prossy is such a hard working lady with a strong drive to succeed.

loans.use: To buying more food stuffs for her restaurant and more goods for her retail shop.

loans.name: Rma Eloisa

texts.es:
La socia es natural D. la ciudad D. Urcos D. la provincia D. Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” D. la Asociación Arariwa. El nombre del banco es D. origen D. la lengua Quechua que traducido al español significa “Cerro D. Oro”. Cusco antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una D. las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio D. la Humanidad y capital arqueológica D. América. 

Nuestra socia IRMA tiene 54 años, es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos que ya no dependen D. ella. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio D. venta y compra D. madera D. la ciudad D. Puerto Maldonado y la venta D. tamales (Es un plato típico del Perú echo a base D. maíz blanco). La socia venD. sus tamales en los buses que van al sur del Cusco, desD. las 6 D. la mañana hasta las 5 la tarD.. Ya son varios años que tiene los negocios y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como maíz pelado y manteca para preparar más tamales. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

La ciudad D. Urcos se encuentra ubicada a 45 km del Cusco siguiendo la carretera asfaltada a Puno, es un pequeño poblado con una hermosa laguna donD., según la leyenda, Huascar lanzó una enorme cadena D. oro para evitar que los españoles se la llevaran.
texts.en:
Irma was born in the city of Urcos, province of Quispicanchis, district of Cusco. She’s a member of the “Qori Orcco” Community Bank, part of the Arariwa Association. The name of the bank comes from the Quechua language, meaning “Golden Hills”. Cusco was once the capital city of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the Peruvian Viceroyalty. The city was declared Patrimony of Humanity and archaeological capital of the Americas. Irma is 54 years old. She’s a single mother of three, although they are all independent now. She divides her time between her household activities and her retail wood store located in Puerto Maldonado and her tamales stand (typical Peruvian dish, maD. of white corn). She sells tamales on the busses that go south of Cusco, from 6am to 5pm. She's been doing this for many years with great success, thanks to her hard work. She’s a working mother and an entrepreneur trying to support her family. She would like to use this loan to purchase more items such are pealed corn and butter to make more tamales. She’s very thankful for this opportunity and she’s committed to fulfill her payments according to schedule. The city of Urcos is located at 45 km from Cusco, following the asphalted road to Puno. It’s a small town with a beautiful lagoon where, according to the legend, Huascar threw a huge golden chain to prevent the Spanish settles to take it away.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items such are pealed corn and butter to make tamales

loans.name: Abekundire Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Isaiah K. is 55 years old and married with 5 children of school age, and he also takes care of 3 dependants. Isaiah has a grocery and farming business in Bufunda Street that he has owned for over 20 years, and he is able to make 400,000/= in profits per month from both businesses.
