texts.en:
The Mujeres Anfitrionas committee was created a little over two years ago thanks to another committee working in the same area at the time.To date, they have successfully overcome many hardships. They have been supportive of members in need. On average, they will receive 696000G which will be invested in inventory for their respective commercial activities.

They are all hardworking woman who use all their efforts to provide for their families. Each is dedicated to an independent activity, as shown below:

1 Sebastiana B. Clothing sales 2 Priscila C. Clothing sales 3 Victoria C. Food sales 4 Viviana C. Cosmetics sales 5 Benita Z. Food sales 6 Rosana C. Cosmetic sales 7 Selva C. Sublease of rooms 8 Selva E. Snacks 9 Carmen V. Seamstress 10 Elvira P. Fruit sales 11 Petrona O. Sales of slippers and wallets 12 Paola S. Clothing sales 13 Ana G. Newspaper sales 14 Andresa S. Seamstress 15 Nadia V. Underwear sales 16 Luisa C. Clothing sales 17 Antoliana A. Clothing sales 18 Zulma D. Healing herbs and teas sales 19 Cynthia B. Groceries 20 Lourdes G. Clothing sales 21 Elisa B. Clothing and handmade slippers sales 22 Tatiana G. Accounting assistant 23 Balbina F. Food sales 24 Irene G. Handmade cards and paitings 25 Antonia S. Healing herbs and teas sales

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and thread for sewing clothing, purchase of t-shirts, shirts, shoes and slippers; purchase of flour, meat, eggs, bell peppers and bread to prepare food, purchase of sodas, beer and wine; purchase of paint and paper to make Christmas cards; purchase of newspapers and magazines; purchase of herbs for mate and terere (teas).

loans.name: Housam

texts.en:
Houssam is a 49-year-old married man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife. Houssam has been working as a blacksmith for a few years already. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials and iron for his work. This is the first time that Houssam has requested a loan.

Houssam is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and iron for his work

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline, age 38, runs a grocery store, selling groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is married with three children and lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Roseline loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she dreams of eventually owning a supermarket. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell in her store. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Mouna

texts.en:
Mouna is a 58-year-old woman who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with her husband. Mouna has owned a bakery for over ten years. She specializes in saj and mankoucheh. A saj is the metal oven used to make saj bread; it is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome. The saj is used to make several types of bread, including markouk (thinned) bread and doughy confections, or mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza; the most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it any time of the day, but it somehow tastes better in the morning. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for her bakery. This is the first time that Mouna has requested a loan.

Mouna is special in her work because she is known for her tasty mankoucheh. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had difficulty building her start-up capital. Mouna decided on doing her business because of her experience; she also wanted to improve her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her store.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her bakery

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Adama BÂ est une femme de 30 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BAKIDIOTO dont elle est la présidente depuis 3 ans et demi et y a bénéficié de 7 prêts qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés sans difficultés. Son crédit lui permet de mieux approvisionner sa boutique en marchandises: elle vend divers produits alimentaires tels que le riz, le sucre, le lait en poudre, l'huile végétale etc... Avec ses bénéfices elle participe aux charges collectives familiales.
texts.en:
Adama Bâ, 30, is married and the mother of 3 children. She is a member of the Village Bank of BAKIDIOTO and has been the president for three and a half years. She has received 7 loans that she has always managed correctly and reimbursed without difficulty. Her loan will allow her to stock her little store better; she sells various groceries such as rice, sugar, powdered milk, vegetable oil, etc. With her profits she helps support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expand her little business

loans.name: Lucienne

texts.fr: Z. Lucienne est née vers 1969 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs 20 ans que Lucienne vit à Dandji à Cotonou. Lucienne est mariée à ASSOCLE Antoine, un soudeur, et est mère de quatre enfants. Certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Lucienne n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Lucienne vend des tissus et également de l’huile de palme, par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Lucienne s’approvisionne. Lucienne exerce cette activité depuis environs 10 ans, et est à son quatrième crédit à ALIDé. Lucienne a bien remboursé les trois crédits antérieurs qu’elle avait obtenus de ALIDé. Lucienne désire élever le niveau de son activité afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients ; mais Lucienne manque suffisamment de moyens financiers pour y arriver. C’est la raison pour laquelle Lucienne sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Z. Lucienne was born around 1969 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Lucienne has been living in Dandji in Cotonou for about 20 years. She is married to ASSOCLE Antoine, a welder, and is the mother of 4 children. Some of her children are attending school. The couple share the responsibility for supporting their family.

Lucienne was never able to attend school. To make a living, Lucienne sells cloth as well as palm oil through the distribution system. She buys her merchandise at the international market of Benin, Dantokpa. Lucienne has been in this business for about 10 years and is on her fourth loan with ALIDé. She reimbursed the three previous loans from ALIDé correctly. She would like to expand her business so that she can better satisfy her customers, but she does not have sufficient financial means to manage this. This is why Lucienne is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of lengths of cloth and jerrycans of palm oil

loans.name: Elohor

texts.en:
Elohor, age 28, lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she has a grocery store business, selling grocery items at retail prices to her customers. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is married and has three children.

Elohor is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad is a 38 year old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife. Ziad works as an electrician, and he also owns a farm where he has had cows for nineteen years. Ziad decided on having a farm which allows him to sell dairy products like milk, cheese, etc. His second job, as an electrician, is the job that he always wanted to do. These two jobs allow him to take care of his family’s needs.

Ziad requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase feed for his cows and tools for his work as an electrician. This is the first time that Ziad has requested a loan.

Ziad is special in his work because he is known for his good dairy products. His clients are his friends and neighbors, as well as people from outside his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. In the future, he plans to keep on improving both of his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his cows and tools for his electrician business.

loans.name: Kossa

texts.fr: Kossa G. est âgée de 47 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BAKIDIOTO depuis 6 ans et a une bonne expérience avec le crédit pour l'avoir contracté à 12 fois de suite. Elle développe un maraîchage et vend parallèlement sur table des condiments de cuisine et des légumes au marché. Elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kossa G., 47, is married and the mother of 7 children for whom she is responsible. She has been a member of the Village Bank of BAKIDIOTO for six years and has a good deal of experience in managing loans since she has had 12 in a row. She is developing her market gardening and also sells kitchen condiments and vegetables on a tabletop in the market. She is working at improving living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expanding her little businesses

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina, age 30, is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is married with four children. She lives and works in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she runs a grocery store business, selling groceries in her store at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she has high hopes of eventually opening a supermarket.

Tina is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Victorina

texts.es:
La  Sra. Victorina tiene 22 años Vive con su marido y una hija menor de edad. 
Ellos tienen una pequeña despensa en su domicilio, ademas el marido se dedica a la venta ambulante de prendas para damas y caballeros, calzados deportivos, aparatos celulares y otros artículos de acuerdo a los pedidos que recibe s.
El crédito será de ayuda para poder adquirir mercaderías para la venta en este fin de año, pues en estas fechas las ventas aumentan y permiten generar mayores ingresos.
Ellos anhelan poder  culminar la construcción de su vivienda y de esta forma seguir forjando un buen futuro para su hija y los hijos que desean tener en el futuro.
texts.en:
Mrs. Victorina is 22 years old. She lives with her husband and young daughter. They have a small retail store at home and the husband also sells clothes for ladies and gentlemen, sports footwear, celular phones and other articles on request.

The loan will be spent on buying merchandise to be sold this season as sales increase and generate higher income. They wish to finish building their home and thus secure a good future for their daughter and the children they plan to have in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cider, bread, various products, soft drinks, meat, cheese, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Issam

texts.en:
Issam is a 55 year old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Issam has owned a cow farm for four years. Issam decided on having a farm because it has always been the family business. This business allows him to sell dairy products like milk, cheese, etc.

Issam requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase feed for his cows and a van for his work, which will allow him to improve his work and distribute his dairy products to houses in his village and the surrounding area. Issam has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time.

Issam is special in his work because he is known for his good dairy products. His clients are his friends and neighbors, as well as people from outside his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his business and to always be able to supplement his family’s expenses.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his cows and a van for his work.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is 36 years old, married, and the mother of three children. With hard work and determination, all her children are in school. She is very resourceful to her family in the provision of food and payment of bills. She is a food vendor and sells kenkey, with fried fish and pepper spice. She sells kenkey in the mornings and in the afternoon. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grain, cooked, and then eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers, since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper.

She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children’s education. She hopes to use part of her profits to improve her savings and business growth.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Ego

texts.en:
Ego, age 51, is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She runs a grocery store business in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she lives. In her store, she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she would like to eventually open a supermarket. Ego is married and has six children.

Ego is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
K. is a 35-year-old married man with two children.  One of his children is currently in school, while his other child is still very young.  In recent months, he has been struggling to provide for his children's basic needs (e.g., education), which has been his greatest challenge.  But he explains that he is constantly working to provide for his children and to pay his bills.  

K. supports his family by working as a trader.  Specifically, for 11 years now, he has been in the business of selling used clothing and bed sheets.  Selling such items is big business in Ghana because brand-new cloths are too expensive for much of the population.  He travels to a nearby city known as Kumasi to purchase his stock of goods.  He is seeking a loan to buy more bales of used clothing.  Normally, he concentrates on selling children's clothing, bed sheets, used towels, etc.  He believes that this loan would help him save for his children's future.  In addition, he hopes that the loan will one day enable him to rent a store where he could trade his goods because he typically sells his goods through hawking.

loans.use: To expand his inventory by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Zulma

texts.es:
La Sra  Zulma se dedica a la compra y ventas de joyas y carteras , ella es soltera con un hijo ya mayor , hace 16 años que se dedica a este rubro , ya que antes trabajaba como vendedora en una distribuidora.
 Ella  necesita de este crédito para la compra de mas joyas ya que llega fin de año y tiene que tener variedad de mercaderíass.En el futuro  desea ampliar mas su negocio y abrir un local propio .
texts.en:
Zulma buys and sells jewelry and handbags. She is single with one grown son. She has been in this line of work for 16 years, and previously worked as a saleswoman for a distributor. She needs this loan to purchase more jewelry, as it is close to the end of the year and she wants to have a variety of merchandise. In the future, she would like to further expand her business and open her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase jewelry and handbags

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: G. Eugénie est née le 22 Mars 1949 et réside depuis environs 16 ans à Davatin à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Eugénie est mariée à BOSSOU Vincent, un agent retraité de la CIMBENIN. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à leur charge. Eugénie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Eugénie n’a fait que l’école primaire. Pour contribuer à assurer les charges familiales, Eugénie mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (fournitures scolaires, sardines, tomates en boîtes, oeufs, épices, cigarettes, sandalettes, bougies, etc.) à son domicile. Eugénie vend également du bois de chauffage à son domicile. Eugénie s’approvisionne à ONAB et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Eugénie exerce cette  activité depuis environs 12 ans, et est à son cinquième crédit à ALIDé. Eugénie a bien remboursés les quatre crédits qu’elle avait obtenus de ALIDé. Eugénie sollicite un cinquième crédit afin d’agrandir davantage son activité et de la diversifier par l’acquisition d’autres produits de divers, pour mieux répondre à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
G. Eugénie was born on March 22, 1949 and has been living in Davatin in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for about 16 years. Eugénie is married to BOSSOU Vincent, a retired employee of CIMBENIN. The couple has 5 children, all attending school, of whom 4 still depend on their parents. Eugénie lives together with her husband and children. The couple share in supporting the family.

Eugénie only got as far as primary school. To contribute to covering family expenses, she sells various items (school supplies, sardines, tinned tomatoes, eggs, spices, cigarettes, flip-flops, candles, etc.) out of her house. She also sells firewood out of her house. Eugénie buys her merchandise at ONAB and at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has worked at these businesses for 12 years and is on her 5th loan with ALIDé. She reimbursed the four preceding loans from ALIDé in a timely manner. Eugénie is requesting a 5th loan so as to expand her businesses and diversify by acquiring various other items, so that she can better respond to her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various products (school supplies, 8 cases of tinned goods, 10 trays of eggs etc.)

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is 37 years old, married, and the mother of two children. All of her children are still in school in the primary level. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, and poly bags, etc. She also sells fried yams to augment her expenses and profit. Ama deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve sales to enable her to save more for the children’s education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana, age 56, lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She runs a grocery store where she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes someday to own a supermarket. She is married and has seven children.

Juliana is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 23 years old, single, and currently in the family house. He lives in a small community which is a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. He is a very hard working gentleman who runs a chemical store and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, malaria drugs, etc. Many local people patronize his drugs as first aid and cures for when they are sick.

He has been in business for five years now and the shop was opened for him by his father. He is among the few people who run a licensed chemical shop in the community. His chemical shop is registered to operate by Ghana pharmaceutical council. He wants to use the loan to buy an increased supply of drugs to include others that are frequently requested by her customers. He hopes to raise a good income to take care of his family. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of pharmaceutical drugs.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena is a 50-year-old married woman and mother of six children. Currently, three of her children are in school, while the rest of her children are independent and live on their own. She works hard to support her husband in taking care of their home.

To earn a living, she is a producer and supplier of local palm oil. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts, and is used to prepare many local dishes like fried fish, soups, and pastries. She produces and supplies palm oil to food vendors so that they can prepare their meals for their customers. She also sells palm nuts to those who need them for further processing. Unfortunately, her palm oil production has been hampered as of late due to insufficient working capital; more specifically, she cannot to afford a machine to assist with palm oil processing. In any event, she is seeking a loan to buy more bags of palm nuts to increase her production of palm oil. She believes that this loan will enable her to save more for her children's education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing a bulk supply of raw ingredients of palm oil

loans.name: Christy

texts.en:
Christy, age 34, lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. In her store, Christy sells baby supplies at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes someday to own a larger store. She is married and has two children.

Christy is requesting a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more baby supplies to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby supplies to sell in her store

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of seven kids. Five of the children are in school, while the rest are learning various professions. She lives with her family in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. Abena is very skillful and a talented hair dresser. For this reason, lots of people have their hair done in her salon, increasing her clientele base and hence her profit margin. With her fifteen years of rich experience, she has managed to train five apprentices who are now on their own. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, hair dryer machines etc., to serve her customers well.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc.

loans.name: Latifatou

texts.fr: A. Latifatou est née le 25 Juin 1976 à Parakou, au Nord du Bénin. Mariée à ADJANBAO Moumouni, un tailleur, Latifatou est mère de sept enfants. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Latifatou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a environs deux ans que la famille vit dans ce quartier. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Latifatou n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Latifatou vend des bijoux et divers autres produits (savons, bombons, cigarettes, lait, sucre, dentifrices, thé lipton, etc.) à son domicile, afin de subvenir à ses besoins. Il y a environs 10 ans que Latifatou mène cette activité. Latifatou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits qui ont été bien remboursés à ALIDé. Latifatou sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour renforcer son activité et accroître sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Latifatou A. was born on June 25, 1976 in Parakou in northern Benin. She is married to Moumouni Adjanbao, a tailor, and the mother of seven children. Some of her children attend school. Latifatou has been living for approximately two years with her children and husband in the neighborhood of Finagnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The parents provide together for their family. Latifatou did not attend school.

Latifatou runs a convenience store from her home to provide for her needs. She sells jewels and various other items, such as soap, candy, cigarettes, milk, sugar, toothpaste, Lipton tea, etc. She has been in this business for about ten years. Latifatou gets her supply in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a long-standing client with Alidé, since she got already three loans which she repaid on schedule. She came now to Alidé and applied for her fourth loan to boost her activity and expand her clientele.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, milk, toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: Nyame Suro Group

texts.en:
Rose is 37 years old and is married with three children. All of her children are in school, which makes Rose so happy. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, and biscuits, etc. in her neighborhood. Rose has been selling grocery items for the last eighteen years to take care of the family. She has no regrets of what she has had to do, but her only challenge is funds to buy more raw materials. She takes delivery of stock from Kumasi central market and retails to her customers. She is therefore requesting loan support. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc., to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Nyame Suro’ which literally means the fear of the Lord. She is the one sitting in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are small traders, food vendors, and farmers respectively. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. They would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water, and boxes of biscuits.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth, age 43, sells sarongs, laces, and bags at retail prices to her customers in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she lives. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Elizabeth is married and has five children. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which will be used to purchase more sarongs, laces, and bags to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, laces, and bags to sell

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael buys building materials in bulk and supplies these to retail shops in her community. She has been in this business for close to 12 years. She started borrowing from LAPO three years ago. Her previous loan allowed her to set up a permanent shop, and she sells and receives her supplies there now; she has finished repaying this loan.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of N140,000, which will to enable her buy building materials in bulk at a discount.

Rachael is 43 years old. Her husband is a civil servant, and they have three lovely children who are in a private primary school. She sends a warm thank you to all Kiva lenders and promises to repay her loan promptly, as she is proud to say that she has always done in the past.

loans.use: To purchase building materials in bulk

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen tiene 45 años, vive al lado de su esposo Zenón,  también de 45 años, y con sus jóvenes  hijos, Doris de 23 y Jessica de 21 años. Todos viven felices y con muchas ganas de progresar en su casa que es propia.Desde hace algunos años se dedica a la venta de salchipapas (platillo compuesto de papas y salchichas fritas),  y le va muy bien en el  negocio ya que la cocina siempre ha sido una de sus principales habilidades. La venta empieza durante  la tarde, ya que por las  mañanas debe dedicarse a las labores del hogar y atender a su familia, además al empezar la noche este  plato es muy requerido por las personas que llegan a sus casas después de un día de larga faena laboral, y  en el camino se les provoca degustar de la salchipapa que prepara Carmen. En un futuro quiere ampliar  su negocio para que le rinda mayores ganancias y aperturar su propio restaurante.Es el  quinto préstamo con  MFP y siempre ha sido muy puntual en  todos los pagos, y promete serlo una vez más porque tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante.Con el dinero del crédito comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería para poder incrementar sus ventas y sus  ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Carmen is 45 years old. She lives with her husband Zenón, also 45, and their children, Doris, 23, and Jessica, 21. They have a happy life in their own house, with a strong desire to get ahead.

For the past several years, Carmen has had a business selling salchipapas; a dish made of potatoes and fried sausage. The business has succeeded because cooking has always been one of her greatest skills. She begins work in the afternoon, as the morning is devoted to household and family chores. This works out well, as her product is very popular with people who stop on the way home after a hard day’s work, tempted by Carmen’s salchipapa.

In the future, Carmen would like to expand her business into a true restaurant, which would yield greater profits. This her fifth loan with MFP. She has always been punctual with her payments and promises to do so again, as she has a great desire to get ahead. With the loan money, she will purchase a larger quantity of ingredients to increase sales and income.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Kitchen supplies and ingredients

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha, age 47, lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers at the market. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes someday to own a supermarket. She is married and has six children.

Martha is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kings Way Group

texts.en:
Rakia is 25 years old, married, and the mother of two children. Currently, all her children attend school. She sells smoked fish, which she started doing three years ago, in the community where she lives. Rakia prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She buys stocks of fishes from the fish mongers in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She has a high customer base, and the customers travel from the other part of the surrounding communities to buy her fish. She is requesting a loan to upgrade her stock of fish. She dreams of giving her children a quality education. So do the other members.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Kings Way’. She is the one sitting in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are small traders, food vendors, and farmers respectively. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. They would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fish and dried fish.

loans.name: Adidja

texts.fr: A. Adidja est née en 1962 à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin. Adidja vit depuis une dizaine d’année au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Adidja est mariée à AFFO Moumouni et est mère de trois enfants. Parmi ses enfants, certains sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Dandji. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Adidja n’a pas été à l’école, mais a appris la couture. Pour aider son mari dans les charges de la famille, Adidja vend également des tissus, des chaussures et même des bijoux. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Adidja s’approvisionne. Adidja mène cette activité depuis environs sept ans. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Adidja voudrait renforcer son capital et élever le niveau de son activité, pour mieux répondre à la demande des clients. C’est la raison pour laquelle Adidja sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Adidja A. was born in 1962 in Parakou in northern Benin. She has been living for about ten years in the neighborhood of Dandji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Moumouni Affo and is the mother of three children. Some of her children attend school. The family lives together in Dandji. The parents provide together for their family. Adidja did not attend school, but learnt the dressmaking craft.

To help her husband with the family charges, Adidja sells cloths, shoes and even jewels. She gets her supply in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this business for about seven years. Adidja is a long-standing client with Alidé, since she got already five loans from Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. She would like to bolster her working capital to increase her activity level and better meet the demand from her customers. This is why she came now to Alidé and applied for her sixth loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloths

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is 41 years old, married, and the mother of four children. Two have finished junior and senior high school respectively, while the rest are still in primary school. To support her household, she sells cereals like maize and groundnuts in the community market to her loyal customers. She says that the sales of these products is very lucrative, and with her nineteen years of experience she will be able to increase her market size with the support of loan assistance. She takes delivery of stock from the nearby communities. Therefore, she wants a loan to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income to support her family, especially the children's education and business expansion. She would be grateful for your loan support.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like groundnut and beans.

loans.name: Zee

texts.en: Zee is forty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Zee is a trader, who trades in second hand bags and footwear. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Zee has been in business for three years and wants to give her business a facelift. She therefore wants the loan to procure more goods.

loans.use: To buy more second hand bags.

loans.name: Prudence

texts.en:
Prudence, age 33, has a business selling tailoring supplies in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria, where she lives. She is client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells tailoring materials at retail prices to her customers. She is also a fashion designer and she makes lovely Nigerian clothing designs for her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Prudence is married and has no children.

She is requesting for a loan amount of 140,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati is 36 years old. She is married and the mother of six children. All of her children are currently in primary and nursery school respectively. She said that her children are in school with the help of Allah. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, and biscuits, etc., in her neighborhood. She lives at Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. With her five years of experience, she has been able to be very supportive of her husband in paying the bills and feeding the children. Fortunately, her business is in a strategic location within the town where she lives. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc., to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is thirty years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. Ama is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called ‘banku’ from corn dough. It is served hot with soup. She sells it at the local school compound. Ama buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is 30 years old, married, and the mother of two beautiful children. Her children are in school in the community where they live. Amalia works hard to support her husband in taking care of the family. She is a trader and trades in goods like scarves, and local slippers for women and children.

She also sells drugs like Viagra and other drugs for those who have low sperm counts. She said her business is doing well as most men patronize the sale of the drugs. She takes delivery of stock from importers and retails them to her loyal customers through selling in the community and its surrounding villages. Amalia has been in business for the last eight years to support her children. She is requesting the loan to buy bulk supply of stock so that she can increase her profits. She saves part of her profits in a bank for future eventualities and hopes to pay back the loan in time. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy drugs, locally made slippers and scarves in bulk.

loans.name: Tomasa Esperanza

texts.es: La señora Tomasa tiene 61 años de edad, procreo cinco hijos, ella trabaja como conserje en una casa campaña desde hace más seis años para poder sastifacer sus necesidades, sus hijos la apoyan ya que sus ingresos son bajos, poco a poco a logrado ir mejorando su casa con el préstamo anterior compro materiales de construcción para hacer un muro, el cual se ha beneficiado ya que tiene mayor seguridad, con este financiamiento comprara materiales para construir el portón principal del porche a si como reparar el que tiene, y pintar las verjas. Para esto comprara: tubos, soldadura, cener, pintura y comenzar hacerlo. Sus planes a corto tiempo es poder poner ropa de venta en su casa ya que entre poco será mas difícil poder trabajar por sus enfermedades el cual espera lograrlo.
texts.en:
Tomasa is 61 years old and has five children. She has worked as a caretaker at a vacation house for more than six years to meet her expenses. Her children help support her, as she earns very little.

Slowly, she has managed to improve her home. With a previous loan, she bought materials to build a wall, which has brought her greater security. With this loan, she will buy materials to build an entrance gate to the porch and paint the railings. She will need iron, welding supplies, paint, and thinner.

Tomasa plans to have a clothing sales business in her house because it will soon be difficult for her to work because of her health. She expects that she will be able to achieve this.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy iron, welding supplies, paint and thinner to build a gate and paint the railings.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is thirty-two. She is married and a mother of two children, both in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in one of the tourist attraction centres in Ghana. Since the community is a coastal town in the region, the majority of the inhabitants are fishermen/women. Faustina is a hairdresser by profession. She has her workshop by one of the streets. She says she has been in business for over thirteen years and wants a loan to buy artificial hair and other working materials to be able to render better services to her valued clients.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair.

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: T. Philomène est née en 1953 et vit depuis 32 ans au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Philomène est mariée à ZODANKPO Adrien, un agent retraité de l’Office des Postes et Télécommunication au Bénin. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Philomène vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Philomène n’a fait que l’école primaire. Pour assurer l’entretien et l’éducation de ses enfants, Philomène vend du charbon de bois et du maïs en gros et en détail, à Synapostel (en face de la pharmacie Saint Martin) à Cotonou. Philomène s’approvisionne à Tchaourou dans le Nord du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu trois crédits qui ont été bien remboursés à ALIDé. Philomène sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, dans l’optique d’agrandir son activité et de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Philomène T. was born in 1953 and has been living for 32 years in the neighborhood of Avotrou in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Adrien Zodankpo, a retired employee of the Post and Telecommunications Office in Benin. They have four children, who all attend school. Three of them are in their care. Philomène lives together with her children and husband. The parents provide together for their family. Philomène attended only elementary school.

To provide her children with care and education, Philomène sells charcoal and corn, wholesale and retail, in Synapostel, opposite to Pharmacy Saint-Martin in Cotonou. She gets her supply in Tchaourou in northern Benin. Philomène is a long-standing client with Alidé, since she got already three loans, which she repaid to Alidé on schedule. She came now to Alidé and applied for her fourth loan, which she will use to expand her activity level and meet the ever increasing demand from her clientele.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 39 años, es una emprendedora mujer que vive al lado de su pareja Rodolfo de 41 años y sus hijos Rubén de 11 y Dayat de 4 años. Todos viven juntos en su acogedora casa que es propia.Desde hace algunos años se dedica  al tejido de prendas de vestir, actividad que realiza muy feliz  ya que es uno de sus pasatiempos preferidos, aprendió desde muy pequeña viendo a su madre que le enseñó todos lo secretos de este creativo oficio. Cada día debe trabajar mediante pedidos de las personas que viven por su zona, ya que todas sus amigas y conocidas  le solicitan los modelos según los colores y diseños que prefieren;  usualmente requieren las prendas para sus hijos(as) ya que es la especialidad de María tejer prendas pequeñas, pero cuando debe hacerlas grandes las confecciona sin problemas. Los pedidos son buenos, y los acaba en el tiempo pactado, es por esta razón  que para  el futuro tiene  pensado ampliar  su negocio, para empezar con las ventas de tejidos al por mayor.Es el  quinto préstamo con  MFP , promete ser responsable y puntual como siempre lo ha sido.Con el dinero del crédito comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería en lana para empezar a  tejer todos los pedidos que tiene pendientes.
texts.en:
Maria is 39 years old; she is an enterprising woman who lives with her partner Rodolfo (41) and their children Ruben (11) and Dayat (4). They all live together in a cozy house that is their own. For some years she has been knitting and crocheting garments, an activity that makes her very happy since it is one of her favorite hobbies. She learned to knit when she was very small watching her mother, who taught her all of the secrets of this creative craft. Every day she must work through orders from the people who live in her area, since all of her friends and acquaintances request her fashions in the colors and designs they prefer. Usually they request these garments for their children, since Maria's specialty is to knit small garments, but when they request something larger she is able to make it without a problem. The orders are good, and she completes them in the time agreed upon, and for this reason she is thinking of enlarging her business in the future by starting to sell knitted garments wholesale. This is her 5th loan with MFP, and she pledges to be responsible and punctual with her payments as always. With the money from this loan she will buy a larger quantity of wool to begin knitting all of her pending orders.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise (wool) so as to continue her creative business

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Salamatu is 37 years old, married, and the mother of four children. Currently, three of her children are in school. She sells smoked and dried fish; she started her fish sales eight years ago at the market in the community where she lives. She buys stock of fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She buys stocks of fishes from the fish mongers sometimes when demand is high. Salamatu also sells porridge prepared from millet and sometimes maize to her customers. She sells the porridge in the morning and right after she switches over to the sale of the fish.

She has a high customer base as a result of her moderate prices, and her good reception towards her customers. She is requesting the loan to upgrade her stock of fish and porridge. She dreams of giving her children a quality education through the proceeds from the business, and she would be grateful for your support to make her dream become a reality.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fish and dried fish.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth, age 55, sells cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is married and has seven children.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan in the amount of 150,000 NGN to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is thirty years old. She is widowed and has three children to care for, all of whom are schooling. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Grace works hard to be able to provide for the family. She trades in utensils. Grace buys from Accra and sells them in her community. She also treks to sell in nearby towns. She has been in business for three years and yearns to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy utensils.

loans.name: Rosmery Susana

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Rosmery tiene 23 años, es conviviente y tiene un hijo llamado Héctor Enrique que tiene dos años y medio.  Ellos viven en la ciudad de Urcos a 45 Km. de la Ciudad Imperial del Cusco. 

La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar y después se dedica a la artesanía y a la confección de chompas de lana de alpaca. Rosmery alquila el espacio donde trabaja y vende la artesanía. Ella trabaja dos tipos de artesanías: muñequería (Confección de Muñecas con trajes típicos de la ciudad del Cusco) y peletería (Confección de alfombras, prendas de vestir y accesorios, adornos con lana de alpaca). Rosmery exporta sus productos a los países de España e Inglaterra. Ya son tres años que tiene el negocio y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre joven, trabajadora y emprendedora que requiere el préstamo para comprar más material como tela, hilos, lana de alpaca, etc., para seguir confeccionando artesanía. 

La socia es natural de la ciudad de Urcos de la provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” de la Asociación Arariwa.
 
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our member Rosmery is 23 years old, has a common law partner and a two and a half-year old son named Hector Enrique. They live in the town of Urcos, located 45km from the Imperial City of Cuzco.

The member gets up very early in the morning to take care of household chores and after that she makes crafts and knits "chompas" (a type of sweater very common in the region) with alpaca wool. Rosmary rents the space where she works and sells her craft. She works in two kinds of craft: the making of dolls with the typical clothing of Cuzco and the knitting of rugs, clothing, accessories and decorations with alpaca wool. Rosmery exports her products to Spain and England. She has had her business for 3 years and it is going very well thanks to all her hard work. Our member is a young, hardworking and interpreneur mother who requests a loan to buy more supplies such as fabric, thread, alpaca wool, etc. for her craft.

The member was born in the town of Urcos, province of Quispicanchis of the provincial department of Cuzco. She belongs to the "Qori Orcco" Community Bank of the Arariwa Association.

The member is thankful for being given this opportunity and will comply with the scheduled payments.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Our member requests the loan to purchase more working materials such as fabric, thread, etc.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia is a thirty-nine year old divorced mother of one child who is currently in school. She lives with her daughter in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to be able to meet the demands of the family. Emilia is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew, from a table top by the road side. She buys bags of rice from nearby towns. Emilia has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.es:
Josefina A. Cotzojay tiene 48 años y vive con su padre, su hermana y la hija de su hermana.  Ella es soltera, y tiene su casa propia.  Ella empezó hace 27 años a vender ropa.  Con su propio capital, podía comprar manteles para vender.  Ahora, que ha crecido mucho su negocio, vende mucha ropa diferente.  

Con este prestamo, ella va a invertir una parte en ropa tipica, y otra parte en fruta para vender.  Por la época navideña, ella tiene demanda para vender estes productios.  La ropa es muy buen producto y también ella vende muchas uvas en este época.

Josefina ha trabajado con FAPE por 2 años, recibiendo prestamos de bancos comunales.  Este prestamo es su primero de Kiva.  Quiere modificar su mercadería por la competencia que existe.  Entre sus sueños, es que tenga un capital fuerte para que pueda trabajar en el futuro sin préstamo, y que pueda retirarse sin la ayuda de otros.
texts.en:
Josefina is 48 years old and lives with her father, a sister, and a niece. She is single and has her own house. Some 27 years ago she began selling clothing. With her own capital, she bought table-cloths to sell. Now, since her business has grown considerably, she sells a lot of different clothes.

With this loan, she will invest a part in traditional (folk) clothing, and another part in fruit to sell. During the Christmas season, there will be great demand for these products. Clothing is a very good product and, also, she sells a lot of grapes at this time.

Josefina has worked with FRAPE for 2 years, receiving loans from communal banks. This loan is her first with Kiva. She wants to modify her merchandise due to competition. Among her dreams is to have a strong capital base so that she can work in the future without loans, and to be able to retire without the assistance of others.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY FOLK CLOTHING AND FRUIT TO SELL

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is 35 years old and is the mother of five children. All of her children are in school from primary to junior high level respectively. To support her household, she sells cereals, like beans, maize, millet, rice and groundnuts, in the community market to her loyal customers. She says that sales of these products is very lucrative and the goods move fast. She has been in business for the last eleven years now, and has lots of experience selling. She takes delivery of stock from the farming communities in the northern part of Ghana, and sometimes in the surrounding villages where she lives.

She is requesting this loan to increase her stock as we approach the Christmas festivities. She believes this loan will enable her to make a good income to support her family, especially their education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like groundnut, rice, maize, millet and beans.

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: H. Léontine est née vers 1966 et vit depuis 24 ans à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Léontine est mariée et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais deux des enfants vivent avec le couple. Léontine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Léontine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a six ans, Léontine s’est mise dans la vente de nourriture (riz et haricot) et des fruits (oranges, plantains, etc.) à Agblangandan. Léontine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Léontine avait bénéficié de trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Léontine sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour élever le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Léontine H. was born around 1966 and lived for the past 24 years in the Sèmè-Podgi commune of Agblangandan, in Benin. Léontine is married and has four children, all educated. Only two of the children live with the couple. Léontine helps her husband with the household expenses. She has only completed her primary education. Six years ago, Léontine began selling food (rice and beans) and fruit (oranges, bananas, etc.) in Agblandangan. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Léontine was already granted three loans from ALIDé, that were reimbursed in full. She now requests a fourth loan from ALIDé, to increase the level of her business and better respond to her customer's needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and beans, two baskets of oranges and three bunches of bananas

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en: Barbara is forty years old. She is divorced and has no children. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She is a hard-working woman. Barbara is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells it on a table top by the road side. She also sells ‘banku.’ Barbara buys bags of rice from nearby towns. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian D. is married and has four children. She has received a junior-high education. Vivian sells onions at the sea shore; she has been doing this since 1980. Her husband is a fisherman. Vivian uses her income to help pay school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase bags of onions for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vivian plans to save to build up her business.

loans.use: Vivian will use the loan to purchase bags of onions for sale.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose, age 34, lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is a client of LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She runs a grocery store where she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers, and she hopes someday to own a supermarket. She is married and has two children.

Bose is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN, which she will use to purchase more groceries to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is forty-five years old. He is married and has five children who are all in school. He lives with his family in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. John works hard to be able to provide for his family. He runs a chop bar and operates a cold store as well. His shop is by the road side. He buys fresh fish directly from the fishermen in the community. John has been in business for four years and desires to improve upon his business. It is his desire to give all his children a good education.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish for sale

loans.name: Lokossi Gisèle

texts.fr: H. Lokossi Gisèle est née en 1967 et vit depuis 27 ans à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à AGBASSE Nazaire, un chauffeur, Lokossi Gisèle est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Parmi les enfants, un n’est plus à sa charge. Lokossi Gisèle vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Lokossi Gisèle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a environs cinq ans que Lokossi Gisèle vend du riz, de la farine de manioc et aussi de la pâte rouge de maïs à la maternité d’Agblangandan. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Lokossi Gisèle s’approvisionne. Lokossi Gisèle est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant bénéficié de quatre crédits auparavant. Les quatre crédits ont été bien remboursés. Lokossi Gisèle sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour rehausser le stock de ses marchandises, afin de mieux faire face aux besoins de ses clients.
texts.en:
H. Lokossi Gisèle was born in 1967 and has lived in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, Bénin, for 27 years. She is married to Agbasse Nazaire, a driver. Lokossi Gisèle is a mother of 4 children; they are all educated and one of them is no longer a dependent. Lokossi Gisèle lives with her children and her husband, and the couple work together to cover family expenses. Lokossi Gisèle did not go to school.
Lokossi Gisèle has sold rice, manioc flour and polenta at the maternity hospital in Agblangandan for around 5 years. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa at the international market of Bénin. Lokossi Gisèle is a long-time Alidé client, having already received and repaid 4 loans. Lokossi Gisèle is requesting a fifth loan through Alidé to increase her stock of merchandise in order to better satisfy customer demands.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, corn, manioc flour and peanut oil
